title: What's going on at Tiger Global?
text:
One scoop to start: Josh Harris, the US billionaire and former top executive at Apollo Global Management, is exploring a bid for Chelsea football club, said people familiar with the matter.

Tech sell-off grabs tiger cubs by the tail

We've posed the question time and time again: what is SoftBank?

But today DD would like to launch a new inquiry about Tiger Global.

Like the elusive Japanese investment group subject to Masayoshi Son's changing whims, the $90bn-in-assets investment firm run by “Tiger cub” Chase Coleman has gained notoriety making aggressive bets on technology companies.

And also like shape-shifter SoftBank, the bullish investment group descended from Julian Robertson's Tiger Management hedge fund dynasty is difficult to pin down.

What started out as a public stockpicking hedge fund under Coleman has evolved into a multipronged operation that has risen to stardom on its private investment funds — overseen by longtime executive Scott Shleifer.

The pandemic had brought about a golden era of billion-dollar tech valuations in which Tiger's move-fast-and-break-things approach dominated, drawing in eye-popping amounts of fresh capital and the ire of Silicon Valley's parochial ranks.

Tiger Global was willing to strike quicker deals for higher prices, and forgo board seats in the process. Traditional venture capital rivals such as Andreessen Horowitz, Sequoia Capital and Accel were forced to move faster and stomach more risk, or chance being edged out of their own territory.

But while Tiger Global continues to make huge bets via its private markets arm, many of the fast-growing yet speculative companies it backed have gone public over the past few years. And they haven't lived up to their sky-high valuations.

Tiger Global and its fellow “cubs” — including Philippe Laffont's Coatue Management, Glen Kacher's Light Street Capital and Andreas Halvorsen's Viking — have been hit by “brutal” sell-offs in technology stocks, our colleagues Laurence Fletcher and Akila Quinio report.

Here are some of the numbers, according to FT sources (markets have continued to fall, so DD's best guess is that these figures have taken a further turn for the worse since they were gathered):

One of the most painful holdings has been Peloton, the fitness group battered by ballooning losses and bad PR in which Tiger Global, Coatue, Light Street and Viking all held positions during 2021.

But unlike that fateful Sex and the City episode, many of the cubs' hedge fund peers saw the fitness group's tour de trouble coming from a mile away.

Odey Asset Management's James Hanbury shorted Peloton until late last year, for instance, according to documents seen by the FT.

“It's amazing they missed it,” said one industry insider whose fund made money betting against Peloton, about the cubs. “It wasn't like these issues were hidden.”

It could be the case that Robertson's cubs are suffering from a case of pack mentality. Many have drawn criticism for significant overlap in their portfolio positions and similar penchants for placing aggressive bets in crowded, overvalued markets.

But if Tiger Global is truly anything like SoftBank, DD ventures to guess Coleman won't appreciate being lumped in with the crowd.

Case in point: partners at the firm are committing $1bn of their own cash to back seed funds that focus on early-stage start-ups, as The Information revealed. Could its latest identity be as a family office?

Consolidation calls in Spain

Spanish telecoms group MasMovil drew a close to a complex love triangle on Tuesday when it announced that it had entered exclusive talks to merge with French rival Orange in Spain.

Vodafone, which had held talks with MasMovil since last year about a possible joint venture or sale of its Spanish business, was left out in the cold.

If approved, the two companies will form a 50-50 joint venture valued at €19.6bn.

MasMovil — which was bought out by a private equity trio of KKR, Cinven and Providence Equity Partners in 2020 — isn't expected to stay private for the long term. Under the proposed merger, Orange would have the right to purchase a controlling stake in the event of a future IPO.

The news could come as a blow to Vodafone, which has been under pressure to strike a deal for its Spanish business and will be overtaken in market share by the newly formed group.

Earlier this year activist investor Cevian took a stake in Vodafone and pushed for an overhaul of the business, adding to the sense of urgency for the British telecoms group.

All isn't lost for Vodafone. Excessive competition in Europe has squeezed prices to a pulp, as Lex notes, where competition authorities have been uninterested in pushing for consolidation. A deal would lift margins for everyone involved as four major players become three.

All parties stand to benefit from a green light from regulators because more European M&A is needed to achieve the scale necessary in the global race to build out 5G networks.

How far is Disney willing to go with sports betting?

Disney's chief executive Bob Chapek likes to say that “the consumer is our North Star”.

When it comes to sports, customers are leading the company known for magic-peddling mice straight to the gambling table.

Hence Chapek's determination to push deeper into sports betting, mainly through ESPN+, the streaming service of its sports cable network which links viewers directly to their online-betting platforms of choice. For legal reasons, DD reckons they won't market it as the happiest place on earth.

Betting, will attract “the younger consumer . . . [who wants] to have gambling as part of their sports experience”, Chapek said during last month's results call.

The question is how Chapek plans to make this happen. Disney's presence in betting is fairly modest. It acquired a 6 per cent stake in DraftKings, a fantasy sports and betting group, when it bought 21st Century Fox in 2019. It also has a deal with Caesars, ESPN's exclusive sports book odds data provider and the owner of the Las Vegas studio where the channel films much of its betting programmes.

A licensing deal with, say, DraftKings, Caesars or its Vegas neighbour MGM would allow ESPN to conquer a larger slice of the market without actually handling the mechanics of taking bets — a distinction that could be lost on some consumers who care about Disney's wholesome, family-friendly image.

(Chapek isn't worried about this, pointing to internal research showing that ESPN's ties to sports betting aren't going to harm the Disney brand.)

Rich Greenfield, an analyst at LightShed, said Disney has other options — including merging ESPN with a sportsbook and creating a separate business. “My gut is they run ESPN as a cash cow and use it to build the Disney Plus streaming business,” he added.

Disney will spend $33bn on content this year, up $8bn from a year ago, as it aims for profitability and about 240mn subscribers by 2024.

“I think there are lots of strategic decisions to make,” Greenfield said. “It's not obvious what those decisions are.”

Job moves

  • Clayton, Dubilier & Rice has appointed Simon Tinkler as a senior legal adviser in a part-time role. He joins from Clifford Chance where he was a partner.

  • Barclays has appointed Corinne Grain as a managing director in senior relationship management, based in Paris. She was previously the bank's head of equities distribution for Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

  • Credit investment firm Canyon Partners has named its chief financial officer Luis Silva, head of European investments, and Davide Amico and real estate co-heads Robin Potts and Maria Stamolis as partners, according to a letter seen by DD. Partner Jonathan Heller and veteran investor Sergey Kamensky are leaving the firm.

  • Sixth Street has hired former TCV partner Nari Ansari as a senior leader on its growth equity investing team.

Smart reads

Survival mode Russia's VTB was meant to rival Europe's biggest lenders. Moscow bankers speak to the FT about how the country's global banking ambitions took a back seat to financing Putin's war machine, and are suffering as a result.

Londongrad's finest Ukrainian oligarch Dmitry Firtash made billions protecting the Kremlin's gas empire in his home country, and was investigated by the FBI for his ties to Russia. Yet the British establishment welcomed him with open arms, the Guardian writes.

Jurassic Park The UK stock market is struggling to attract tech listings. It must boost valuations and shake its dinosaur image, or risk extinction, Lex writes.
